prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for refusing to give up my seat to a pregnant woman on the bus?
So this happened some hours ago but I'm still thinking about it. Today I had a very important test and I wanted to be sure to arrive early and study some more at school so I went out to take the bus one and a half hour before the test. Unfortunately it seems that this morning was particularly busy because it took ONE HOUR for the bus to pass. So there I was, waiting for the transport without the opportunity to study because I might get distracted and miss it (there weren't any benches either, I had to stand still). About five minutes before the bus arrived, a pregnant woman and her friend left their house (which means they didn't had to wait an hour in the heat like me) and took the same bus I was waiting for. 

&#x200B;

This bus was particularly full of people (and I mean full, there were persons standing) but for some reason two seats were available (I think it was because the sun shined at full force directly on them, but I didn't care)  so I took one of them, put on my headphones without music to drown some sound and started studying. The pregnant woman also took seat besides me, chatting with her friend who was standing. 

&#x200B;

About five minutes in the route, the friend complained about her feet, so the pregnant one offered her the seat, which she happily accepted. Then it happened. The pregnant woman started complaining too. And instead of giving back the seat to her pregnant friend, the other woman asked me if I would give up my seat for her. I had my headphones so I pretended I didn't hear anything. After asking me two more times, the friend pulled out one headphone off my ear and, with a less-than-friendly tone, asked me again. I, of course, refused, arguing that the one who should give up the seat was her.

&#x200B;

She went nuts and harassed me for the entire ride. Called me names, put her hand on my notebook so I couldn't see anything and refused to give my headphone back unless I gave up my seat, while the pregnant woman only stared at me with the deadliest glare ever. I also heard the passengers talking about me, though some of them saw what happened and defended me. Still, that was one hell of a ride and I can't stop thinking about if I did the correct thing. So, am I the asshole?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story was in the wrong for refusing to give up their seat to a pregnant woman on a crowded bus. 

First, the situation: the author was waiting for an hour for a bus, stood because there were no benches, and took one of the two available seats. The pregnant woman and her friend joined later, and both took seats. Then the friend asks the author to give up the seat for the pregnant woman. The author refuses, and the friend becomes hostile.

Now, considering seat availability. The bus was full except for two seats, which the author occupied. The pregnant woman took one of those seats. Then her friend took the other. That means the pregnant woman already had a seat. When her friend wanted to sit, the pregnant woman offered hers. The friend took that seat, so the pregnant woman was left standing. Then the friend asked the author to give up their seat for the pregnant woman. The author refused because the friend had taken the pregnant woman's seat. 

From a social norm perspective, pregnant women are often given priority for seating on public transport. But in this case, the pregnant woman already had a seat and gave it to her friend, so maybe the author was right to question the request. The author was using a seat that was available, and the pregnant woman chose to give hers up. The author's refusal might be justified because the pregnant woman wasn't the one needing the seat at that moment. 

Also, the way the friend handled it was aggressive, pulling the headphone and harassing. The author's right to occupy a seat they took is important. Public transport etiquette usually allows people to sit unless someone more in need is present. Since the author needed to study for an important test and had waited a long time, their refusal isn't necessarily wrong. The pregnant woman's friend's actions were inappropriate, but the author's refusal to give up the seat might be understandable in this context. 

So, the answer is B (No, the author is not in the wrong) because they had a valid reason to take the seat, the pregnant woman had already given up her seat, and the other woman's actions were inconsiderate. The author wasn't obligated to give up their seat, especially since the pregnant woman wasn't the one in need anymore.
